label: Pre-reader / Emergent
reading_level_description: Most children are in phonics stages 2–5. Cannot decode independently. All content must be supported by audio.
vocabulary_notes: Concrete nouns and action verbs only. No abstract concepts without physical anchor. Examples: dog, apple, jump, big, one more.
tts_notes: ALL text must be voiced. Do not display text without audio. Use expressive TTS voice — not robotic.
sentence_structure: Subject + verb + object only. No subordinate clauses.
agent_content_prompt: Do not display text to child without audio. All questions must be spoken aloud. Use only objects the child knows from everyday life (animals, food, toys, family). Maximum one concept per screen. Avoid negatives ('which is NOT...') — rephrase as positives.

label: Emergent Reader
reading_level_description: Consolidating phonics (stages 5–6). Many can read simple sentences but decode slowly. Text should support, not replace, audio.
vocabulary_notes: Common concrete nouns plus simple abstractions (e.g., feelings, seasons, simple cause/effect). High-frequency words accessible. Subject vocabulary must be spoken and displayed simultaneously.
tts_notes: TTS required for all main content. Individual word tap-to-hear available. Parent can disable for fluent decoders.
sentence_structure: Simple sentences. And/but connectives allowed. No embedded clauses.
agent_content_prompt: Use short sentences with common words. Read all questions aloud. Display text simultaneously with audio so children can follow along. Introduce subject vocabulary with a spoken definition before using it in a question. Avoid compound sentences with more than one clause.

label: Developing Reader
reading_level_description: Most children are independent readers of simple texts. Reading fluency varies widely. Decoding is largely automatic for common words.
vocabulary_notes: Subject vocabulary with inline glossary support. Abstract concepts grounded in familiar contexts. Similes and comparisons helpful (e.g., 'solid is like a brick').
tts_notes: Available on demand. Recommended for EAL learners and those with reading difficulties.
sentence_structure: Simple and compound sentences. One subordinate clause maximum. Fronted adverbials acceptable.
agent_content_prompt: Use clear, active sentences with one idea per sentence. Subject vocabulary can be used if first introduced with a definition. Avoid passive voice. Metaphors and similes are helpful for abstract science concepts. Questions can require 1–3 word written answers or spoken responses.

label: Fluent Reader (Emerging)
reading_level_description: Children are broadly fluent readers of age-appropriate fiction and non-fiction. Reading for understanding is replacing reading to decode.
vocabulary_notes: Curriculum vocabulary expected to be known (with in-context reminder). Some academic vocabulary (e.g., 'evidence', 'conclusion') acceptable. Technical terms in context.
tts_notes: Available on demand. Default off for most learners. Useful for dyslexia accommodations.
sentence_structure: Complex sentences with multiple clauses. Passive voice occasional (when natural). Relative clauses acceptable.
agent_content_prompt: Full sentences and paragraphs appropriate. Academic vocabulary can be used with brief inline definition on first use. Passive voice where natural to the subject domain. Inference questions should require child to quote or paraphrase evidence. Avoid rhetorical questions without clear response mechanism.

label: Fluent Reader
reading_level_description: Children are confident, independent readers. Can engage with non-fiction, technical, and literary texts. Reading stamina sufficient for multi-paragraph extracts.
vocabulary_notes: Academic vocabulary expected. Technical domain vocabulary accessible with in-context clues. Figurative language (metaphor, personification) appropriate.
tts_notes: Available for accessibility. Not required for typical Y5 learner.
sentence_structure: Full complex and compound-complex sentences. Passive voice normal. Technical registers (scientific, historical) expected.
number_range: whole numbers, fractions, decimals, negative numbers, percentages
agent_content_prompt: Write as for a confident upper-primary reader. Multi-sentence explanations acceptable. Academic vocabulary without definition if it is curriculum-expected. Questions can require paragraph-length written responses. Use domain-specific register (e.g., scientific language for science tasks, historical present for history).

label: Proficient Reader
reading_level_description: Children are proficient, critical readers. Can engage with complex, multi-layered texts. SATs reading-level texts typically at 700–900 Lexile.
vocabulary_notes: Academic vocabulary expected without scaffolding. Literary vocabulary (connotation, imagery, personification) established. Etymology useful for unfamiliar vocabulary.
tts_notes: Accessibility only. Dyslexia, EAL, or visual impairment use cases.
sentence_structure: No restrictions appropriate to the age. Literary, technical, and academic registers expected.
number_range: all primary number types including ratio and proportion
agent_content_prompt: Write at upper-primary reading level without simplification. Academic and subject-specific vocabulary without definition. Questions can require extended written responses with argument structure (claim + evidence + reasoning). Expect children to engage critically — 'Why might this interpretation be debatable?' is an appropriate prompt.

label: Secondary Transition Reader
reading_level_description: Entry to secondary school. Reading levels vary widely due to school transitions and reading habits. Expect to encounter academic non-fiction registers regularly.
vocabulary_notes: Secondary curriculum vocabulary including discipline-specific terms. Etymology and morphology appropriate (e.g., prefixes, roots). Formal academic register expected.
number_range: full secondary number including algebra, ratio, proportion, basic statistics
agent_content_prompt: Secondary academic register. No vocabulary scaffolding unless for specialist domain terms. Expect students to engage with multi-source analysis, compare interpretations, and construct written arguments. Short-form analytical responses (100–200 words) appropriate.

label: Established Secondary Reader
reading_level_description: Confident secondary learner. Engages with diverse text types including primary source documents, data tables, and literary criticism.
vocabulary_notes: Specialist vocabulary in each discipline. Metalanguage about text (e.g., 'the author's implicit bias') appropriate.
number_range: full secondary including algebraic expressions, standard form, probability
agent_content_prompt: Full secondary academic register. Specialist vocabulary expected. Multi-paragraph analytical writing standard. Source evaluation and argument construction central. Responses can be 150–300 words. Assume willingness to engage with debatable or contested claims.

label: GCSE Preparation Reader
reading_level_description: Approaching GCSE level. Can engage with challenging texts including political speeches, scientific papers (simplified), and 19th-century prose.
vocabulary_notes: GCSE-level academic vocabulary. Command words (analyse, evaluate, compare, justify, assess) must be explicitly taught and used correctly.
sentence_structure: Full GCSE academic register. Command vocabulary (analyse, evaluate, discuss, justify) central.
number_range: full GCSE including surds, trigonometry, simultaneous equations, vectors
agent_content_prompt: GCSE academic register. Use command words explicitly (analyse, evaluate, compare). Responses should follow subject-specific mark scheme structures (e.g., AQA-style AO1/AO2/AO3 for English; method marks for Maths). Multi-paragraph extended responses (200–400 words) standard. Expect critical engagement with evidence quality and interpretive validity.
